On 24 September 2020, the Government announced changes to Australia’s insolvency framework to better serve Australian small businesses, their creditors and their employees. The changes, which commenced on 1 January 2021, introduce new insolvency processes suitable for small businesses by reducing the complexity, time and costs required.  The changes will enable more Australian small businesses to quickly restructure in order to survive the economic impact of COVID-19. Where restructure is not possible, businesses can wind up faster, enabling greater returns for creditors and employees.  These reforms are the most significant changes to the Australian insolvency framework in almost 30 years. They form part of the Government’s JobMaker plan to ensure Australia emerges from the pandemic with a stronger, more resilient and more competitive economy. The need to give businesses and their creditors certainty is crucial to kick-starting confidence and activity as the economy transitions to the recovery phase.  /web/20210201223455/https://business.gov.au/risk-management/emergency-management/coronavirus-information-and-support-for-business/temporary-relief-for-financially-distressed-businesses

South Australia  Patients need a referral from their GP in metropolitan and regional SA to access home-based COVID-19 testing services. Victoria  The free Call-to-Test service can provide in-home COVID-19 testing to Melbourne-based Victorians who are unable to leave their home to get tested. Tonga has three Covid-19 testing machines, 2 purchased and one donated by WHO. The testing lab is on Tongatapu. These workers will presumably need a negative Covid-19 test certificate for travel.    Following the coding rules for H2 the decision is made to leave this at "1" on the basis that three machines  may not offer the capacity for widespread testing of symptomatic or asymptomatic individuals.

The first suspected case of Covid-19 occurred on 4th March.  Descriptions of the response to this case suggested that it may have been quite comprehensive and could have been coded as a "2" (comprehensive).  To date however, with borders closed, no confirmed cases and strict quarantine requirements for repatriating flights, the contact tracing response has not to date been tested.  Following the coding rules, it has not been possible to assess the capacity of contact tracing and so a code of "1" was chosen to reflect at minimum that detailed contact tracing is employed in some cases.
